38723642.review: A casual puzzle game with soothing music. You get a couple of hours of enjoyment out of it.

38159484.review:
Chime doesn't deliver the same kinetic satisfaction provided by most falling block games, but it succeeds because of its incredible soundtrack and its novel mechanic, which is kind of a mix between tangrams and Tetris. You fill in the board with random shapes, and a line crosses the screen from left to right and eventually removes square shapes and "paints" the area they occupied, but leaves behind polygonal detritus that you have to fill in carefully so they become squares too. As you rinse, wash, and repeat, the music changes and gets more elaborate based on your ability to score higher, get combos, and "paint" more of the board.

Did I mention the soundtrack? Yes, yes I did. It makes Chime one of my favorite "zone out" puzzle games.

37662498.review: Need something to relax? Try this game.

37499433.review: Prostě skvělý relax pro všechny příležitosti. Škoda jen že při vypínání občas seká počítač ;)

36589373.review: I only play this game when I am drunk or high. Seriously. One of my top drunk/high games. It's so relaxing and fun!

35188893.review:
in short: It's good. Tetromino puzzler mixed with music mixed with a bit of Qix.

You place tetrominos on a grid to try and create quads, blobs that cover up part of the grid. Ideally, you want to cover as much of the level as possible, make as many quads as possible, etc. It works similarly in some ways to the old Atari classic Rampart--minus the whole Army/Castle minigame stuff, of course.

The neat variation is that there is a beatline sweeping left to right across the grid, which plays a basic music track (and they're good--well known electronic artists like Moby and Philip Glass) but then layers elements into that track based on the position of your quads. So you might get an EDM track where vocal elements or percussion suddenly show up because you've created a quad in a new area. Pretty nifty.

I'm sure some reviews will say it's zen-like but it really isn't... there's prety good pressure throghout the game to rush the tetromino placement, but the gaem does offer a 'free' mode to play around in as opposed to just the timed (3 min, 6min, 9min) modes.

Pleasant game, well worth the minimal time investment.

34523300.review: This is seriously good puzzling fun with great music.  The easier modes start off pretty relaxing, but even they can get hectic once one's gone on long enough!

33712339.review:
This is an interesting concept that needs a lot more to make it a good game. But for a couple bucks, meh. It's not a bad game, it just has some...issues.

The concept is that you place pentaminos in an effort to make large quadrangles. Music is playing behind it and beat bar sweeps across the field. Different sections of the field, once covered by a quadrangle, respond to the passage of the beat bar by playing a portion of the music that had been previously muted. If you've ever worked with a DAW, then you have a rough sense of how this works.

Of course, this means that in the beginning, almost none of the song is playing. By the end, if you've bothered to play, you'll likely hear most if not all of the song. This is great when the song is something worth listening to. The nature of the play though, lends itself best to repetitive electronica of some stripe, and that's what you get. The reason it lends itself to repetitive electronica is because repetitive electronica is extremely repetitive with gradual changes to a phrase you hope is more than eight bars long. 

The repetition of repetitive is deliberate. If you found the repetition of repetitive grating, you'll also find it the repetition of the repetitive music grating.

If you play it more than once, the grating will also be repetitive.

Some songs are worse than others. The Moby track is bad, but it isn't the worst. The best, of course, is "Still Alive", but this version of it is pretty stretched out even if you play the three minute version.

You can see everything this game has to offer in an hour or less. There are leaderboards, but like most leaderboards, may as well be considered set in stone, and probably involved and exploit of some sort.

If it had more than six levels, I'd play them once or twice, so I'm recommending it. Just don't expect a lot from it.

Tetris remains king of block placing games. This one doesn't even approach Dr. Mario.

32914573.review: Good game that need more levels.

32856032.review:
MUSIC TETRIS! Build rectangles out of the shapes, listen to quite well known video game songs and observe them grow with the ground you cover. It is a nice and easy concept, but boy the time mode is hectic and challenging. The six different songs are well chosen (including Portal), and the free mode without the timer is a nice relaxing experience with the right song. It's a kind of tetris that makes music! That's cool.

Follow me as a curator at http://store.steampowered.com/curator/28337205-Fair-Minded-Witness/?appid=298050

32706732.review:
Chime is a beautiful puzzle game that seemed to give Lumines a run for its money when I first played it. You have to place pentominoes down on a grid and create rectangles with them so the line that sweeps through in time with the music can play the sound they produce (changes depending on the shape of the rectangle) and then delete them from the board, highlighting the area that they covered. Your goal is to highlight the entire board to get a point bonus, start fresh with a clean board, and repeat the process. Each of the six songs sound wonderful and I really love both the mechanic of the music getting more [i]involved[/i] the better you do and the mechanic of different-shaped rectangles making different sounds makes each play session feel fresh, similar to Lumines.

[strike]So basically, throw Lumines out the window.[/strike]

Sounds great, looks great, plays great, I'd recommend Chime if you're a fan of puzzle games, musical games, or a mixture of the two.

[strike]No really, physically and digitally remove all of your owned copies of Lumines, Chime hecking ownsssssss.[/strike]

32052654.review:
Use tetris-inspired shapes to make rectangles to fill a grid under variably intense time pressure, while one of six tracks of chill ambient music plays, that sort of changes a little based on your rectangles.  It wants to be a rhythm game, but it's easier and less repetative to play it muted.  One could use freeplay mode as a remarkably limited way to remix / improvise along with the six provided music tracks, but eh.  Eh?   Eh.

Not a bad fidget toy, and a decent arcadey space-filling puzzle, but it doesn't really know what it wants to be.

Contains a portal-themed level with corresponding achievements.  Expect to hear the same two notes alternating for the entire level, while bombarded with distracting portal sounds.  Every 10-20 seconds, a line of lyrics from Portal 2's "Stay Alive" will play.

31877193.review:
Do you like Tetris, but wish it was more annoying and somewhat pointless?   Do you like music, but don't know about Spotify?  Then this may be the game for you!

It's like a freeform tetris but with a time limit as you arrange the pieces into blocks instead of finishing lines.   This has some relationship to litsening to the bundled music by artists such as Philip Glass, but not much.  

You can save yourself some money by playing Tetris and listening to iTunes or internet radio or something.  This game was developed for a charity so you might consider buying it for that reason, although it's probably better to just donate money to a cause of your choice and play Pong.

39567408.review: Sans doute mon jeu préféré. Une musique du tonnerre (même si j'aimerais encore plus de choix), et un concept de tetris vraiment 2D super addictif. J'adore!
